title: 105_hr3157
content:
The "Teachers in the Classroom Act" may be cited as the short title of this Act. The findings section follows. Congress finds that enrollment in elementary and secondary schools is at record levels, with an expected increase of over a million students in 1998. The increase in student enrollment will continue for the next decade, requiring the hiring of 150,000 additional teachers. This growth will particularly impact high poverty urban and rural areas, as well as states with rapid population growth. The increase in student enrollment in elementary and secondary schools will require hiring 150,000 additional teachers over the next decade. Research shows that students in smaller classes learn more in the early grades and continue to outperform their peers even after returning to normal-sized classrooms. It is crucial to adequately educate America's children for the future and improve the learning environment without adding to the Federal bureaucracy or deficit. Congress needs to fund positions for teachers to improve the learning environment without increasing the Federal bureaucracy, deficit, or debt. Resources are needed to accommodate growing enrollment and potentially reduce classroom sizes. The grant program is established to fund positions for teachers and improve the learning environment without increasing bureaucracy, deficit, or debt. The Secretary of Education can award grants to Governors for hiring teachers to reduce overcrowded classes. Governors must apply to receive the grant, and local educational agencies must establish a trust fund to hire new teachers within 2 years of receiving funds. The agency receiving funds must use them to hire new teachers or qualified personnel within 2 years. They must follow accounting practices set by the Governor, allow access to records, ensure a net gain in teachers, review personnel performance annually, limit employment to one year, repay unspent funds after 24 months, and only use the funds to supplement existing resources. The agency must limit employment to one year, repay unspent funds after 24 months, use funds to supplement existing resources, and apply for funding annually. SEC. 4. DISTRIBUTION OF FUNDS. Each State receives funds based on the average number of children aged 5-17. Unused funds are reallocated to other States. SEC. 5. FISCAL REQUIREMENTS. The agency must adhere to specific fiscal guidelines. SEC. 5. FISCAL REQUIREMENTS. A Governor can withhold payments to a local educational agency for noncompliance with section 3(c) after 60 days notice. The agency must increase teachers or qualified personnel to continue receiving funds. A Governor receiving a grant under this Act must select local educational agencies to alleviate overcrowded classes. They must evaluate and report on funds used by the agencies, allocate up to 2% for administrative costs, and up to 10% for innovative teaching programs. The Act requires more than 10% of funds to be used for improving instructional quality through innovative teacher training programs, alternate certification procedures, or hiring nontraditional personnel. The Secretary of Education must report on program effectiveness and make recommendations for program continuity annually. SEC. 7. CONSTRUCTION.

This Act does not guarantee job tenure for personnel hired under it.

SEC. 8. DEFINITION.

For this Act:
- "local educational agency" means a board of education or similar authority in a State
- "State" refers to the 50 States and the District of Columbia
- "Secretary" means the Secretary of the Department of Education

SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Funding authorized for this Act:
- $500 million for fiscal year 1999
- $1 billion for fiscal year 2000
- $1.5 billion for fiscal year 2001
- $2 billion for fiscal year 2002
- $2.5 billion for fiscal year 2003.
